message.content:
Oxalis purpurea, also known as Purple Wood Sorrel, is a perennial plant species that belongs to the Oxalidaceae family. 
It typically grows up to 6 inches tall and 12 inches wide and has a mounding habit. 
The leaves of Oxalis purpurea are trifoliate, meaning that they have three clover-like leaflets that are dark green on top and pale green on the bottom. 
The flowers of Oxalis purpurea are small and bell-shaped, with five petals that are typically a deep shade of purple. 
This plant prefers well-drained soil and partial sun, and is known for its drought tolerance. 
Oxalis purpurea is often used as a groundcover or edging plant in ornamental gardens. 
It can be found in various places such as meadows, wooded areas, and along roadsides in the United States.
